title: An Evening with Katerina Stoykova
brief_description: Katerina Stoykova is back in Kentucky and we're hosting the North American debut of her two most recent books.
description: Katerina Stoykova is back in Kentucky and we're hosting the North American debut of her two most recent books: Bird on the Window Sill (Publishing House Signs, 2017), the bilingual book of thoughts and sentences, and her most recent collection of poetry How God Punishes (Broadstone Books, 2017).

title: Rooted Words: Kentucky Writers on the Land
brief_description: ROOTED WORDS includes paintings and oral histories of Kentucky writers, exploring the relationships between people and places, language and land
description:
ROOTED WORDS includes paintings and oral histories of Kentucky writers, exploring the relationships between people and places, language and land. Participants include Wendell Berry, Nikky Finney, Barbara Kingsolver, Noah Adams, Crystal Wilkinson, Maurice Manning, Gray Zeitz, Mary Ann Taylor-Hall, Jonathan Greene, Leatha Kendrick, Erik Reece, Bobbie Ann Mason, Mark Schimmoeller, and Richard Taylor. Art and interviews by Arwen Donahue.


The exhibit will be on view from March 9 through May 6.


Gallery Hop reception: March 16, 5:00-8:00 pm


Author reading and oral history listening party: April 19, 6:00-7:30 pm at the Farish Theater, Central Branch, Lexington Public Library. Reception to follow at the Downtown Arts Center.

title: Dolores Screening at The Lyric
brief_description: With intimate and unprecedented access, Peter Bratt's Dolores tells the story of Dolores Huerta, among the most important, yet least-known, activists in American history.
description:
With intimate and unprecedented access, Peter Bratt's Dolores tells the story of Dolores Huerta, among the most important, yet least-known, activists in American history. Co-founder of the first farmworkers union with Cesar Chavez, she tirelessly led the fight for racial and labor justice, becoming one of the most defiant feminists of the 20th century.


This Women's History month, join us for a free community screening followed by a Q&A session with KFTC Member Meta Mendel-Reyes and Milton Meza from the Kentucky Dream Coalition!


Meta Mendel-Reyes is Chair of Kentuckians for the Commonwealth (KFTC), and Associate Professor of Peace and Social Justice and General Studies at Berea College, Kentucky. Before becoming a professor, she spent fifteen years as a labor organizer, including four years with migrant farm workers in California. She is the author of Reclaiming Democracy: The Sixties in Politics and Memory (New York: Routledge, 1995). She also served for four years on the Leadership Team of Showing Up for Racial Justice (SURJ), which organizes white people to take action for racial justice.

.


Watch the trailer here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w2W-q55HNEQ

title: Gallery Hop Reception: Esther Chin
brief_description: Chin's multi-disciplinary installation of textiles and sculptures immerses the visitor in a transcendental space, in which textile structures create alternative environments where nature and the body intertwine.
description:
Join us for the reception for Esther Chin's solo exhibition during your March Gallery Hop!


Chin's multi-disciplinary installation of textiles and sculptures immerses the visitor in a transcendental space, in which textile structures create alternative environments where nature and the body intertwine. Using ecological sourced crushed silk, plastics, and repurposes objects, Chin weaves a narrative of the joys and losses that occur female-center communities.


Chin pulls in the vibrant colors and materials of Jamaica, where she was born. Raised by her grandmother and mother, she redefines motherhood as a state of continual intergenerational connection and interpersonal creation. Time is tracked in this state of being by sculptural representations of the stages of her mother’s illness. Diagnosed only 36 months before she died, Chin’s mother is the catalyst for the emotional rigor and upheaval expressed in her work, which culminates in a world of separation, grief, and ultimately, renewal and healing.

title: Thriving Artists Series: OPPORTUNITIES
brief_description: This series is comprised of three candid conversations about the internal and external motivations for making art.
description:
This series is comprised of three candid conversations about the internal and external motivations for making art. No matter what medium you use or what your level of success may be, there are still ways to clarify your artistic vision and achieve more visibility. The UK Art Museum can help. Director Stuart Horodner will serve as facilitator for the series. 

OPPORTUNITIES 

Opportunities are everywhere, they are taken and bestowed. Do you know what they are and how to get them? We will share strategies for finding out about what is available, focusing on regional and national possibilities and how to best take advantage of them.

Each event is 6-8 pm at the UK Art Museum. FREE



Questions? Contact Kate Sprengnether at ksprengnether@uky.edu or 859. 257.6218

title: LGBTQ Histories and Archives Panel Discussion
brief_description: Join us for an intergenerational dialogue about the discovery and preservation of queer histories in Kentucky and beyond.
description:
Co-Sponsored by UK Office of LGBTQ* Resources


Join us for an intergenerational dialogue about the discovery and preservation of queer histories in Kentucky and beyond. How are stories of love, partnership, bravery, illness, and activism, documented and used to inform and educate audiences today?

Participants include Ruth Bryan, University Archivist at the UK Libraries Special Collections Research Center; Dr. Jonathan Coleman, Curator and Assistant Director at the Mary Todd Lincoln House, Co-Director of the Faulkner-Morgan Pagan Babies Archive; Robert Morgan, artist and Co-Director of the Faulkner-Morgan Pagan Babies Archive; Joey Orr, Andrew W. Mellon Curator for Research at the Spencer Museum of Art, University of Kansas.

Moderated by Stuart Horodner.


For information contact Kate Sprengnether at Ksprengnether@uky.edu or 859.257.6218

title: Weedeater: a reading with Robert Gipe
brief_description: Weedeater picks up six years after the end of Robert Gipe’s first novel, Trampoline, and continues the story of the people of Canard County, Kentucky.
description: Weedeater picks up six years after the end of Robert Gipe’s first novel, Trampoline, and continues the story of the people of Canard County, Kentucky. In Weedeater, the reader finds Canard County living through the last hurrah of the coal industry and the most turbulent and deadly phase of the community’s battle with opioid abuse. The events it chronicles are frantic, but its voice is by turns taciturn and angry, filled with humor and stoic grace.

title: An Inspired Evening honoring Ouita Michel
brief_description: We are honoring Ouita Michel, as inspiring chef, restaurant owner and force in the culinary community. Proceeds from An Inspired Evening support all of the ambitious exhibitions and public programs we present throughout the year.
description:
Join us for An Inspired Evening, the UK Art Museum’s new fundraising soiree and an unforgettable night of fabulous food and drink, special performances, and glee throughout the galleries! We are honoring Ouita Michel, as inspiring chef, restaurant owner and force in the culinary community. Proceeds from An Inspired Evening support all of the ambitious exhibitions and public programs we present throughout the year.


Enjoy small bites from Tyler McNabb (Holly Hill Inn),

Tanya Whitehouse (The Food Connection at UK),

Josh Smouse (Honeywood), Sorella Gelateria, and

DaRae and Friend’s Catering.

Music by Italian Beaches.

Event design by Maui Crane.

Entertainment by Sora Contemporary Circus.


Tickets: $75 each, available online: http://bit.ly/inspiredtickets.


Presented by VisitLEX.


For more information, contact Kate Sprengnether: ksprengnether@uky.edu or 859-257-6218.


Supported by:

Jim Albisetti; Creation Gardens; Dwell Kentucky; Miller Edwards Rambicure & Scott White; River City Distributing; Smiley Pete Publishing; The Summit at Fritz Farm; Trek Advancement; Uk Alumni Association; West 6th Brewing; and Woodford Reserve.

title: Leonard Cohen Tribute Encore
brief_description: Hallelujah: The Leonard Cohen Tribute is back by popular demand
description:
Hallelujah: The Leonard Cohen Tribute is back by popular demand at the Lyric Theatre on April 28. Tickets are on sale at the Lyric Theatre box office: www.lexingtonlyric.tix.com and 859-280-2218.


The sold-out November 2017 show featured 35 Central Kentucky artists coming together in 13 acts to bring their considerable talent and respect to Cohen’s incomparable catalog. Two new performers will join the original artists in the reprise: 17-year old multi-instrumentalist and soulful vocalist, Daisy Helmuth, and Paul K, a staple of the Lexington blues and folk scene in the 90’s.


Original artists include One Lane Bridge, Colin Fleming, Paper Moon Trio, Quantum Mechanics, Four Leonards (and a Fifth), The Sherry Sebastian Trio, The Partisans, Doc Feldman with Art Shechet, The Joanna James Trio, Nevi’im, and Lauren Hill, Lorne Dechtenberg and Diane Arnson Svarlien.


“A startling Leonard Cohen Tribute…If there was a single concert event that underscored a sense of community this year it was the November summit honoring the songs of Leonard Cohen. There were wonderfully unspoiled and inventive interpretations of Cohen’s often prophetically poetic works that culminated with the artists and the audience singing ‘Hallelujah’ together…A rich and stylistically far-reaching overview.” -- Walter Tunis / Lexington Herald Leader


“For six decades, Leonard Cohen revealed his soul to the world through poetry and song—his deep time and timeless humanity touching our very core. Simply brilliant. His music and words will resonate forever.” –Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, 2008

Co-produced by the online cultural affairs publication UnderMain and Purple Carrots Productions.


Get your tickets early. The first show sold out quickly!
